awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Quantifying the Effects of Nonlinear Wave-particle Interaction in the Inner Magnetosphere
awd_abstract_narration:
Whistler waves are radio waves produced at very low frequencies by lightning. They are believed to have an important role in the dynamics of the radiation belts and broader magnetosphere. This work will involve theoretical and observational studies of these waves and their interactions with relativistic particles in the magnetosphere. The results have direct applications in space weather models, which are a priority set out in the National Space Weather Action Plan. Additionally, two graduate students will be supported and collaborations will be strengthened between plasma physicists and space physicists at multiple institutions.

To quantify nonlinear wave-particle resonant interactions, three questions will be addressed (i.e., objectives) in this project: (1) how often sufficiently intense whistler waves are detected in the inner magnetosphere, which will provide the occurrence rate of nonlinear wave-particle interactions; (2) how to describe the impact of intense whistler waves on electron flux evolution, which will provide a theoretical tool to evaluate electron distributions in the geospacer system with nonlinear wave-particle interactions; and (3) what is the effect of nonlinear wave-particle interactions on wave generation and damping, which will provide a validated model of the nonlinear wave growth/damping rate in the inner magnetosphere. Each of the three objectives combines observational (from THEMIS and Van Allen Probes) and theoretical investigations.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In absence of particle collisions in very rarified space plasma the wave-particle resonant interaction plays a crucial role energy and momentum exchange between charged particle populations, and thus contribute to the configuration and dynamics of various space plasma systems. In the near-Earth space environment (see schematic), such interactions (1) alters bow shock thickness and dynamics, (2) controls solar wind transport across the magnetopause, (3) participates in magnetic energy release in the magnetotail reconnection, (4) contributes to field-aligned current dissipation in the magnetotail, (5) determines the radiation belt formation and dynamics, (6) controls charged particle precipitation to aurora and (7) their acceleration in the aurora region, and participates in energy redistribution in many other space plasma systems. This guarantees a broad impact of theoretical results devoted to modeling of wave-particle resonant interactions.

 The basic concept describing wave-particle interaction is the quasi-linear theory, proposed in early 60s, which is based on the assumption of charged particle stochastic scattering by plasma turbulences with sufficiently broad wave spectrum. However, as high-resolution wave measurements become available, the applicability of quasi-linear theory becomes questionable. Intense, coherent waves in the Earth magnetosphere can lead to effective momentum exchanges between particle populations and support anomalous plasma transport and energy dissipation. However, their resonant interaction with charged particles is nonlinear and cannot be described by the quasi-linear theory. Therefore, the main goal of this project was to advance our understanding of nonlinear resonance interactions in the inner magnetosphere, where statistics of wave characteristics are most comprehensive. The project was focused on electron resonances with intense whistler-mode waves, one of the most important wave modes controlling electron flux dynamics in the inner magnetosphere.

The main project outcome is the developed approach for modeling of nonlinear (going beyond the quasi-linear diffusion models) resonant interactions. This approach is based on the mapping technique for Hamiltonian systems. The classical example of this approach is the Chirikov map (http://www.scholarpedia.org/article/Chirikov_standard_map), which describes particle diffusion and is widely used for systems with wave-particle resonances. Within this project we generalize such a map for a system with nonlinear resonant effects. The basic explanations of the concept of this approach can be found in Scilight article devoted to one of the main publications of this project: https://aip.scitation.org/doi/10.1063/10.0001127. Within the project the prosed approach has been verified with a series of spacecraft observations and numerical simulations.
